The role of Li and the mechanism in the Li/MgO catalyzed oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) are still under debate. Two Li/MgO catalysts with similar Li concentrations but very different catalytic performances in OCM reactions were studied by using 7Li NMR spectroscopy. 5-coordinated Li ions are present after the catalysts are calcined in air, activated in O2 and used for OCM reaction, and their relative concentrations differ significantly in the two catalysts. Such changes can be ascribed to different numbers of oxygen vacancies, leading to distinct catalytic properties for the two Li/MgO catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 7Li NMR Li/MgO Coordination number O vacancy OCM 1 Introduction Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a direct route to convert methane, the main component of natural gas, to C2+ hydrocarbons, i.e., ethane and ethylene [1–3]. This process enables on-site conversion of methane into more valuable chemicals and avoids its high transportation cost. OCM attracted further research interests, due to the depletion of crude oil reserves and the increasing demand for using methane as an alternative feedstock for chemicals. However, no economically feasible OCM process was developed yet, owing to low yield and poor stability of catalysts, and extensive research is still underway to gain fundamental understanding of this reaction. In a huge number of catalysts tested for OCM, Li doped MgO (Li/MgO) materials were one of the first studied, and their catalytic performances are still among the best [4,5]. Despite the enormous efforts made to investigate the structure and catalytic properties of Li/MgO in the past 35 years, a lot of key aspects are still unclear in literature, including the active center of the catalyst as well as the reaction mechanism. On the basis of the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) data, [Li+ O −] was first proposed as the active center for Li/MgO by Lunsford and co-workers [6,7], which was once widely accepted. However, no signal attributed to [Li+ O −] was observed in more recent EPR studies [8]. Based on experimental observations and theoretical calculations, the doped Li was considered as a modifier that may alter the surface structure, morphology, defects or exposed facets rather than generating the [Li+ O −] active center [8-19]. Nonetheless, the role of Li is still under intense debate for Li/MgO catalysts and remains a subject of active research. Solid-state NMR spectroscopy is a powerful tool that can provide detailed local structure information at atomic/molecular scale. 6Li and 7Li isotopes are NMR active and both 6Li NMR and 7Li NMR have been used extensively to study the local structure of lithium containing materials, especially lithium battery materials [20]. It is therefore surprising that there was few studies applying 6,7Li solid-state NMR to investigate the structure and properties of Li/MgO catalysts [21]. Compared to 6Li, which has an integer spin quantum number (I = 1), the half integer quadrupolar nucleus 7Li (I = 3/2) has a much higher natural abundance (93%) and gyromagnetic ratio (γ(7Li)/γ(6Li)=2.64), resulting in larger receptivity [22]. Since the Li contents in the catalysts are relatively low (see below), 7Li magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectroscopy was applied to investigate the lithium local environments for most of the samples in this study. Two Li/MgO catalysts, which have different initial Li concentrations in the starting materials, were chosen, and the results expected to provide more insights in the role of Li and the mechanism for OCM. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparations Li/MgO samples (with initial Li concentrations of 1.3 and 5.6 wt% Li) were prepared by mixing the desired amount of Li2CO3 (AR, > 98.5%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd) and MgO (AR, > 98.5%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd) into 100 mL deionized water with stirring at 60 °C for 4 h. After stirring, the resulting powder was washed thoroughly and dried at 60 °C overnight, followed by heating the powder in a muffle furnace (Shanghai Laboratory Instrument Works Co., Ltd.) in air at 800 °C for 4 h. The obtained samples were then activated at 450 °C in O2 atmosphere (flow rate: 50 mL/min) for 2 h, before they were applied as the catalysts for the OCM reaction in a mixed gas of 8% CH4, 4% O2 and 88% Ar (flow rate: 100 mL/min) at different temperatures at 650 to 750 °C for 30 mins. The samples after these thermal treatments are denoted as x-Li/MgO-800-Air, x-Li/MgO-450-O2 and x-Li/MgO-650-OCM (for the catalysts reacted at a temperature of 650 °C), respectively, where x is the initial wt% of Li dopant. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) characterization was performed with a Philips X'Pert Pro-Super diffractometer with Cu Kα irradiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) images were recorded on a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area was determined by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 M and the samples were heated at 180 °C in nitrogen before the measurement. The amount of Li were determined with an Optima 5300DV inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) measurements were performed on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR spectrometer equipped with an in-situ low-temperature and vacuum DRIFTS reaction cell (Harrick Scientific Products, Inc.) to enhance the chemisorption with minimum interference of gas-phase molecules. Each DRIFTS spectrum was measured with 128 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1 using an MCT/A detector. Prior to the CO adsorption experiment, the sample was degassed at a base pressure of 0.01 Pa and cooled to the desirable temperature, whose spectrum was taken as the background spectrum. CO was then admitted into the reaction cell to reach the desirable pressures via a leak valve, and the DRIFTS spectrum were recorded after the chemisorption reaches the steady state. 6Li and 7Li magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker Avance III 400 spectrometer equipped with an 89 mm wide-bore 9.4 T superconducting magnet, at Larmor Frequencies of 58.8 MHz and 155.5 MHz, respectively. After the catalysts were calcined in air, activated in O2 and used for OCM reaction, the samples were packed into 3.2 mm rotors inside a N2-filled glove box without exposure to moisture or air, and spun at 20 kHz for NMR data acquisition. Li2O was used as an external standard for quantitative analysis. An excitation pulse width of 1 μs, corresponding to a solution π/8 pulse, was used in the single pulse MAS NMR measurements. An optimized recycle delay of 20 s was used for 7Li NMR experiments, while a recycle delay of 5 s was applied in additional 6Li NMR experiments. Both 6Li and 7Li chemical shifts were referenced to 1 M LiCl solution at 0.0 ppm. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The catalyst activation and catalytic test of Li-MgO materials for oxidative coupling of methane were performed with an ambient-pressure fixed-bed flow reactor (a homemade quartz reaction tube with a tubular electric furnace (Longkou Xianke Instrument, Co., Ltd.)). 0.5 g catalyst (x-Li/MgO-800-Air, 40–60 mesh) was loaded in the quartz tube before it was activated in pure O2 (flow rate: 50 mL/min) at 450 °C for 2 h. Then the gas was switched to the reactants consisting of 8% CH4 and 4% O2 balanced with Ar (flow rate: 100 mL/min). The catalyst was heated to desired reaction temperatures from 650 to 750 °C and kept at the temperature for 30 min and the catalytic reaction reached a steady state. The composition of effluent gas at the steady state was analyzed with two online GC-14 gas chromatographs. One was equipped with carbon-zeolite column and TCD detector for the separation and detection of CH4, CO and CO2; the other with Porapak Q column and H2-flame ionization detector for the separation and detection of C2H4 and C2H6. The conversion of CH4 was calculated from the change in CH4 concentration in the inlet and outlet gasses. The selectivity of C2H4 or C2H6 was calculated as twice the amount of produced C2H4 or C2H6 divided by the amount of converted CH4. All the gasses used were provided by Nanjing Tianze Gas Co., Ltd. 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns of the Li/MgO samples with different initial Li contents do not change significantly after calcination at 800 °C in air, activation at 450 °C in O2, or OCM reaction at 650 °C (Figure S1). All of the diffraction peaks can be indexed to MgO and no peak due to Li2CO3 or other magnesium/lithium-containing phases can be observed. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping image also shows that Mg ions are evenly distributed and there is no sign of Li only phases (Figure S2). These results indicate that the majority part of the sample maintain MgO structure after doping Li and the lattice structure does not change during activation and reaction. 7Li solid-state NMR spectra of the samples after different thermal treatments are shown in Fig. 1 . First, we noticed that the optimized recycle delay should be 20 s for quantitative measurement of Li/MgO samples (Figure S3), indicating a relatively long longitudinal relaxation time (T 1) in the order of several second. Such long T 1 implies that the paramagnetic [Li+ O −] species do not seem to be present. Due to a relatively fast MAS rate of 20 kHz, the intensities of the spinning sidebands in the spectra are low (<10%) and only the center band is quantitatively analyzed. The obtained 7Li NMR spectra are plotted such that the intensities of the resonances should reflect the amounts of Li in the samples directly and it is clear that a large amount of Li is lost during thermal treatments, which is confirmed with ICP results. The total amount of Li in each sample determined with 7Li NMR and ICP is shown in Fig. 2 a-2b and Table S1. Initially, the amounts of Li2CO3 added to MgO in the starting materials correspond to Li weight percentages of 1.3 and 5.6% in MgO, respectively. However, after calcination at 800 °C in air, the Li weight percentages in both samples (1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air and 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air) reduce significantly. Since the decomposition of Li2CO3 starts at around 800 °C but completes at a much higher temperature of 1076 °C, the loss can be ascribed to the evaporation of Li2CO3 and its decomposition product Li2O [23,24]. Based on the ICP data, the weight percentage of Li in 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air is only 0.16%, meaning that 88% Li is lost during the calcination in air at 800 °C, while 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air has 0.20 wt% of Li, corresponding to a 96% loss of Li in the initial mixture. It should be noted that 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air still has a slightly larger Li concentration than 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air at this stage in spite of a greater fraction for Li loss. Activation at 450 °C in O2 further decreases the fractions of Li in each sample. The concentrations of Li in 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2 and 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2 are determined as 0.027 wt% and 0.028 wt%, respectively, showing that both catalysts have lost more than 97% Li and now have almost the same concentration for Li species. A final OCM catalytic process at 650 °C does not change the amounts of Li much in the catalysts, indicating the Li species are stable in the catalytic process after the catalysts are activated in O2. These quantitative NMR results prove that Li desorption occurs in both catalysts in these thermal treatments in air and O2. Eventually the Li concentrations of both catalysts become the same at approx. 0.027 wt%, possibly related to the maximum solubility of Li in the MgO lattice [25]. It is apparent that more Li species is lost in 5.6-Li/MgO catalysts in the first two thermal treatments, the ones with a higher initial Li concentration. This significant Li loss in the Li/MgO catalysts and the observation that both catalysts reach the same Li concentration are in agreement with previous elemental analysis and synchrotron radiation photoelectron data [17]. Although the samples 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2 and 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2 have practically the same actual Li concentrations, the OCM reactivity of the latter is much greater than the former (Fig. 3 and Table S2), while both are much higher than MgO itself (Figure S5). The two catalysts also differ in the C2 selectivity (Fig. 3 and Table S2). For example, the C2 selectivities at 650 °C are 40% and 56% for 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2 and 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2, respectively. The catalyst that has a higher initial Li concentration is not only associated with a higher reactivity but also a significantly higher C2 selectivity, at both 650 and 700 °C. Thus, the microstructure of the two catalysts, which control their catalytic properties, should be distinct [17], while the total concentration of Li should not be the determining factor for the OCM reaction. Therefore, the 7Li NMR spectra are examined more carefully to illustrate the differences in the structure of the catalysts. In all of the samples, a major peak at around 0.1 ppm and a shoulder at a higher frequency (approx. 1.4 ppm) can be observed. It is known that the 6Li/7Li NMR shift decreases with increasing coordination number. For example, 6Li MAS NMR spectrum of Li4SiO4 shows 4 resonances at 1.5, 0.8, 0.2 and −0.7 ppm (Figure S6), which can be assigned to LiO3, LiO4, LiO5 and LiO6 environments, respectively [26]; while 4-coordinated Li ions in Li2O and 6-coordinated Li species in Li2CO3 resonate at 3 and 0.2 ppm in the 7Li NMR spectra (Figure S7), respectively [27,28]. No apparent peak is observed at 3 ppm in our data, therefore, there is no or very limited amount of 4-coordinated Li in the samples and the 7Li NMR resonances at 0.1 and 1.4 ppm are assigned to 6-coordinated and 5-coordinated Li environments, respectively. The absence of the peak at 3 ppm suggests that there is no Li2O in the catalysts, indicating that all of Li2O, which may be generated in the decomposition of Li2CO3, evaporates. It is also clear that the relative intensities of the two peaks at 1.4 and 0.1 ppm are quite different in the two samples. The shoulder peaks at higher frequencies in the 5.6-Li/MgO catalyst at different stages are consistently stronger than the corresponding 1.3-Li/MgO catalysts, indicating the fractions of 5-coordinated Li in the former are greater than the latter. The 7Li NMR spectra observed are quite broad, presumably because of the different local environments of Li and the large 7Li-7Li homonuclear dipolar interactions, even at these low Li concentrations [22]. This may be ascribed to the phenomenon that Li species tend to form separated phases [29]. In order to decrease the spectral width, 6Li MAS NMR spectroscopy was performed since 6Li has a smaller gyromagnetic ratio. However, the S/N ratio is too poor to extract quantitative information (Figure S8). Therefore, it is challenging to perform deconvolution on the 7Li NMR spectra and extract the exact fractions of different Li species. Here the heights of the peak at the shoulder and peak maximum are used directly to estimate the relative concentrations of Li ions with different coordination numbers (Fig. 2c). The fraction of 5-coordinated Li in 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air is 44%, which is about 22% higher than that of 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air (36%). After the activation process in O2, the fractions of 5-coordinated Li in 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2 and 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2 are 40% and 32%, respectively, both of which decrease approximately 4 percentage point. After OCM reactions, the fractions of 5-coordinated Li increase slightly to reach 37% and 47% for 1.3-Li/MgO-650-OCM and 5.6-Li/MgO-650-OCM, respectively. These extracted values for the relative concentrations confirm that the fractions of 5-coordinated Li species in 5.6-Li/MgO catalysts are significantly larger than 1.3-Li/MgO catalysts. Despite the debate on the detailed structure of the Li/MgO catalysts, as well as the roles of Li in OCM reactions [2,17,30], it is the common understanding that the major defect sites in Li/MgO catalysts include LiMg (substitution of Mg2+ by Li+) in the MgO rock salt lattice structure. Since all of Mg2+ ions are 6-coordinated, 6-coordinated LiMg species are expected, which is in agreement with the observation of such species in 7Li NMR. At the same time, the presence of 5-coordinated Li in 7Li NMR clearly indicates that some LiMg ions are connected to an oxygen vacancy. Due to the charge difference between Li+ and Mg2+, the formation of oxygen vacancies is favorable to balance the negative charge introduced by Li+. In particular, an oxygen vacancy (OV, or F2+-center) between a pair of LiMg is considered the most favorable (i.e., LiMg-OV-LiMg) [8]. In this case, only 5-coordinated LiMg ions are present and two nearby sites are charge compensated with one OV, which contribute to the 7Li NMR peak at 1.4 ppm. However, the formation energies calculated based on different defects models show that the situation is more complicated and different local environments of oxygen vacancies may be present [14], which also agrees with our observation of a higher concentration of 6-coordinated LiMg ions. For example, defect complex LiMg-OV−Mg-O-LiMg (i.e., two LiMg are separated) is also desirable. The local environment of such complex is associated with one 5-coordinated and one 6-coordinated LiMg ion, while one more Mg ion is connected to OV, compared to the case for LiMg-OV-LiMg. Nonetheless, the above energetically favorable models have the LiMg site compensated by an oxygen vacancy that is directly connected (i.e., LiMg-OV). Therefore, these oxygen vacancies are Li-assisted vacancies, and their presence and concentration should be directly related to the 5-coordinated Li species in the sample, giving rise to the 7Li NMR peak at 1.4 ppm. At the same time, the presence of 6-coordinated Li ions in the NMR data can be ascribed to the LiMg sites which are not directly connected to OV (e.g., LiMg* in LiMg-OV−Mg-O-LiMg*), as well as a small amount of undecomposed small/amorphous Li2CO3 particles [8], likely on the surface of MgO. Since the relative intensity of the peak arising from 6-cooridnated Li is consistently higher than the resonance of 5-coordinated Li, for both 5.6-Li/MgO and 1.3-Li/MgO, the unreacted Li2CO3 must dominate the 6-coordinated Li species considering that generating 6-coordinated LiMg* should also form the same number of 5-coordinated LiMg, as in LiMg-OV−Mg-O-LiMg*. Comparing the relative intensity of the peak at 0.1 ppm, a larger fraction of Li species are in the form of Li2CO3 in the 1.3-Li/MgO catalysts, possibly related to the higher surface area (Fig. 3 and S9). The relatively high concentration of unreacted Li2CO3 is also consist with the presence of large 7Li-7Li homonuclear interaction in the samples. Based on the analysis on NMR results, it is confirmed that the 5.6-Li/MgO catalysts consistently have a higher fraction of 5-coordinated Li ions (7–10 percentage points), thus more Li-assisted oxygen vacancies, than 1.3-Li/MgO catalysts. Although oxygen vacancies can also form on the pure MgO material, Li-assisted oxygen vacancy formation is apparently more energetically desirable and thus these defects dominate. Therefore, it can be concluded that the total oxygen vacancy concentration is higher in the 5.6-Li/MgO catalyst, which is associated with a higher initial Li content. The higher catalytic activities and C2 selectivity associated with this catalyst suggest that oxygen vacancies are active sites and they are selective towards C2 products [31]. Since the two catalysts have almost the same Li content, our results also imply that Li is a structure modifier instead of active center, and the total Li concentration are not related to C2 selectivity, which agrees well with a lot of previous reports [8-19]. Because O ions are also coordinated to Mg, the formation of LiMg-OV environment upon doping Li should also increase the concentration of lower-coordinated Mg ions, which is supported with FT-IR and electron microscopic studies. There are two bands at around 2148 and 2167 cm−1 for 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air, corresponding to CO adsorbed on 5- and 4-coordinated Mg sites on the edge of the common (100) facets, respectively [32,33] (Fig. 4 a). The peak at 2167 cm−1 dominates in the data with low CO pressure, while the relative intensity of the band at around 2148 cm−1 gradually increases with the increasing CO pressure, suggesting that the adsorption of CO on 5-coordinated Mg sites is weaker than 4-coordinated Mg sites. In contrast, several new IR peaks at 2196, 2120 and 2050 cm−1 are observed in 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air (Fig. 4b). The increase in intensities of these new peaks are different from the bands corresponding to CO adsorbed on Mg sites, and can be attributed to the contribution of CO adsorbed on the surface Li species [19]. At the same time, with increasing CO pressure, the peak at 2148 cm−1 due to 5-coordinated Mg ions becomes less prominent and the peak at approx. 2160 cm−1 dominates due to CO adsorbed on 4-coordinated Mg sites, indicating that the concentration of lower-coordinated Mg sites in 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air catalyst is much higher than that of 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air. Representative HRTEM images of 1.3-Li/MgO and 5.6-Li/MgO catalysts after different thermal and catalytic processes are shown in Fig. 5 . The MgO lattice fringe of 0.212 nm can be observed in both 1.3-Li/MgO-800-Air and 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air, corresponding to MgO{200} facets, in which Mg ions are coordinated to five O ions. However, in 5.6-Li/MgO-800-Air, the lattice fringe of 0.152 nm can also observed, corresponding to MgO{220} facets, where the coordination number of Mg ions is reduced to 4. Such difference can be ascribed to the stabilization effects by incorporating Li in the MgO structure. Similarly, even the lattice of 0.249 nm, arising from MgO {111} facets, can be observed in 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2, in which the Mg ions are 3-coordinated. At the same time, only MgO{200} facets can be found on 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2. The situation after the OCM reaction resembles. Both {220} and {200} facets are present on 5.6-Li/MgO-650-OCM, while only {200} facets are observed on 1.3-Li/MgO-650-OCM. These data show that doping more Li leads to lower-coordinated Mg on high energy facets, which is also consistent with our NMR data and literature [9,10]. Based on the catalytic results and the above experimental observations, we propose the following occurs in the formation of Li/MgO catalysts. During thermal treatment of the Li/MgO catalysts in air and O2, a large fraction of Li2CO3 evaporates, leading to significant decrease in the total Li content in the sample [17]. At the same time, only a small fraction of Li ions are able to replace lattice Mg ions and reconstruction of surfaces occurs, while some unreacted Li2CO3 stay on the surface of the catalyst. Due to the charge differences between Mg2+ and Li+, a significant amount of 5-coordinated Li ions and oxygen vacancies are formed due to Li incorporation. In the samples with a higher initial Li concentration (5.6-Li/MgO catalysts), more vacancies can be generated due to the a larger amount of Li available for incorporating into the MgO lattice, as compared to the samples with a lower initial Li level (1.3-Li/MgO catalysts). These oxygen vacancies are responsible for the OCM activity and the selectivity for C2 products. Eventually, 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2 has more oxygen vacancies, and less unreacted Li2CO3, possibly owing to a smaller surface area related to surface reconstruction, as compared to 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2. Therefore, despite a very similar total Li concentration in both 5.6-Li/MgO-450-O2 and 1.3-Li/MgO-450-O2, the former has a higher reactivity and higher selectivity toward C2 products. 4 Conclusion Two sets of Li/MgO catalysts were investigated with 7Li solid state NMR spectroscopy. 5-coordinated Li ions in these samples were detected for the first time with NMR, and their fractions were extracted. Despite a very similar Li total concentration of the two catalysts, a larger fraction of 5-coordinated Li species, found in the catalysts with a higher initial Li concentration (5.6 wt%), help the formation of more oxygen vacancies. These Li-assisted oxygen vacancies lead to a higher OCM reactivity and C2 selectivity, while the total Li content is not directly related to the catalytic performances. coredata.dc:description: The role of Li and the mechanism in the Li/MgO catalyzed oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) are still under debate. Two Li/MgO catalysts with similar Li concentrations but very different catalytic performances in OCM reactions were studied by using 7Li NMR spectroscopy. 5-coordinated Li ions are present after the catalysts are calcined in air, activated in O2 and used for OCM reaction, and their relative concentrations differ significantly in the two catalysts. Such changes can be ascribed to different numbers of oxygen vacancies, leading to distinct catalytic properties for the two Li/MgO catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: 7Li NMR investigations of Li/MgO catalysts for oxidative coupling of methane
